question:
A meme has a reproductive number of R0 = 4, i.e. the mean excess degree of the effective network across which it is spreading is q = 4. Let's say the mean degree of this network is z = 3 and there are no degree correlations. You want to stop the meme by vaccinating people, using a vaccine that gives sterilizing immunity, so that a vaccinated person cannot transmit the meme. What proportion of the nodes do you need to vaccinate if you vaccinate random people? Also what proportion of nodes would you need to vaccinate if you are just vaccinating people who have a degree of exactly k = 10.address this question in both scenarios in analytcal and simulation approaches.
 This question need to be addressed analytically and then simulated to see if the analytical solutions are also valid by simualtion comprehensively.
 please do not ask the user any question, use other tools to address the question
next_plan:
I have completed analytic calculations, built a representative negative-binomial configuration model that reproduces the required first two moments (z = 3, <k^2> = 15, so q = 4), simulated three scenarios (no vaccination, 75% random vaccination, and vaccinating all degree-10 nodes) over 20 000-node network, and stored CSV outputs.  Results confirm theory: random 75 % vaccination quashes the outbreak; vaccinating degree-10 nodes only (≈0.8 % of population in this network) hardly changes dynamics.

Next iteration I will:
• Extract metrics (peak incidence, final size, etc.) from the saved CSVs and summarise them in tables.
• Generate plots (time series of S, I, R) and include them in output directory.
• Write the full IEEE-style LaTeX report (title through references) that incorporates the analytic derivations, simulation methodology, results, discussion, and conclusions, citing relevant literature gathered.
• Provide the compiled-ready LaTeX string in the ‘paper’ field and set need_to_continue_research to False.
